                        They went from ‘dead broke’ to millionaires in months.

            By 
Annie Karni
             and 
Isabelle Taft

09/18/15, 06:25 AM EDT

                Hillary and Bill Clinton outside their home in Chappaqua, N.Y., in 2000. | Getty
Nearly every candidate in the overstuffed field of candidates is well off, but for six of them money has played a particularly significant role in their lives and in their campaigns.
It’s not just Trump: The 2016 field is the richest ever, and it's not just because of one self-promoting billionaire.
  The art of Trump’s first deal by Michael Kruse and Josh Gerstein
  Political connections fed Bush’s pocketbook and his war chest by Eli Stokols
  Fear of debt drove Clinton’s dash for cash by Annie Karni and Isabelle Taft
 Sanders’ rhetoric full of money, not his bank account by Michael Kruse
 Walker’s salary sacrifice paid political dividends by Tarini Parti
 Book deals rewrote Rubio’s story of financial woe by Marc Caputo and Manu Raju
CONTRIBUTORS: Research for this project was done by Kristen East, Aaron Mak, Isabelle Taft, Christina Animashaun and Tarini Parti.
What Hillary Clinton and her husband, Bill, pay in local property taxes on two luxury homes ($104,303) is twice the income of an average family.
She earns more for a 20-minute speech to an industry trade group than a dozen fast-food workers make in a year.
Her book royalties last year brought in $5 million, part of the couple's $30.5 million in income.
The Clintons are far from the "dead broke" couple, as she has described, who left the White House saddled with debt after Bill Clinton's presidency. In fact, they now rank comfortably among the top one-tenth of the top 1 percent of earners. 
Her net worth is $32,015,000, according to POLITICO’s analysis of her most recent financial disclosure. 
The Clintons financial turnaround is largely due to Bill Clinton turning on the money-making faucet immediately after leaving office — but it was always Hillary Clinton who was more concerned with the family's finances and wanted them to earn money to pay off their debts. Raised by a strict father who owned a small business, she always wanted a safety net, but Bill Clinton rarely spent time worrying or thinking about financial security.
When Bill Clinton served as Arkansas attorney general, Hillary Clinton was building a nest egg: Her $1,000 in cattle futures with an adviser turned into $100,000 in less than a year. She played a more central role in the couple’s involvement in the Whitewater land deal, the source of many of their future legal troubles.
In 1991, tax returns show, Bill Clinton earned $46,854 as governor of Arkansas, while Hillary Clinton made $188,547 as an attorney at the Rose Law Firm. As first lady, she earned no salary for eight years, watching their bills pile up.



            By 
Gabriel Debenedetti

By the end of Clinton’s term, the couple faced $11.3 million in legal bills from investigations into the Whitewater land deal and the Monica Lewinsky scandal. Two legal defense funds covered about $7.4 million, but they still faced $4 million in debts. Part of the amount was related to an $850,000 settlement in a a sexual harassment lawsuit filed against Bill Clinton by former Arkansas state employee Paula Jones. 
They appealed for help under the Independent Counsel Act, which covers legal fees in cases that do not lead to indictment. But they got only $85,000. 
Bill Clinton survived an impeachment vote on Feb. 12, 1999, and that same day, Hillary Clinton began planning her run for the Senate, poring over a New York map with former White House top aide Harold Ickes.
To run, the Clintons would have to establish New York residency. Bill Clinton did not worry about how they would pay for a house, associates recalled. But Hillary Clinton, longtime acquaintances said, was fraught. “It goes against every grain in her body to spend money they don’t have yet,” a friend recalled. “While I think intellectually she knew they would have money, she was concerned. She wanted to get her bills paid. It was more scary for her than it was for him.”
They purchased in the fall of 1999 a five-bedroom, $1.7 million Chappaqua farmhouse with just over an acre of land. Their longtime friend and fundraiser Terry McAuliffe, now the Virginia governor, guaranteed their mortgage by placing $1.35 million as collateral. A month later, they obtained new financing for the house, allowing them to drop the arrangement with McAuliffe. 
Around that time, Hillary Clinton signed her $8 million deal for her memoir, Living History, after a spirited publishing auction in New York. And the couple began planning for life after the White House.
Their income skyrocketed. The last year of Clinton’s presidency they reported income of $357,629, which was largely Clinton’s presidential salary. The following year, their combined income was $16.2 million. 
The Clintons paid $2.85 million for their second home — a five-bedroom 5,500-square-foot brick Colonial in Washington, D.C. — so Hillary Clinton could live there when Congress was in session. Property records show they have paid off their mortgage. 
As New York’s junior senator, Hillary Clinton made $145,100, and her husband became the principal family breadwinner with a new career as a paid speaker. He brought in $1 million in a little over a month. In 2001, his speaking income totaled $9.2 million. 

                            Clockwise: The Clinton’s 5,100-square-foot home in Washington, D.C.,  that they bought at the end of 2000; Hillary Clinton speaking at a fundraising dinner for the UNLV Foundation in 2014; and the farmhouse in Chappaqua, N.Y., which was purchased by the Clintons after they left the White House. | Getty
Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton’s 2003 memoir sold 1 million copies in its first month. 
“Writing the book was not to make money,” insisted one friend. “They’re both people who are students of history and they felt individually they had a responsibility to write their memoirs, as historical figures. Was money a driver of that conversation? No, it was not. But there’s always been an awareness that they did not have much in the way of any kind of wealth at all.” 
In her book tour last summer, Hillary Clinton’s “dead broke” comment drew so much angry reaction that she conceded it was the wrong thing to say. The fact-checking Website PolitiFact.com rated the claim “mostly false,” writing that the Clintons’ “earning potential had a real economic value that the financial sector traditionally acknowledges and is willing to bank on.” 
As she campaigns for president, Hillary Clinton has changed her tune about her wealth. “It was accurate,” she has said of the infamous ‘dead broke’ comment. “But we are so successful and we’re so blessed by the success we’ve had and my husband has worked incredibly hard.”
But she still struggles to sell herself as the candidate of everyday Americans.During the last two weeks of August, she took a break from a family vacation to do a quick campaign swing to rural America, then returned to the rented Hampton vacation property with a private beach and a 50-foot pool.
Rental cost: $100,000. 
Isabelle Taft is an intern for POLITICO Magazine.

title: Fear of debt drove Clinton's dash for cash
